posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: I have a full set of FRC components (rio, pdp, sparkmax, cim, neo, neo 550) that I took home for the summer to test code on.  However, I don’t have a battery.  How should I power the system?  I don’t have a full power supply, and I’d rather not buy one if there’s an alternative. Thanks

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: Powering through the wall might have unexpected outputs relative to a normal robot. This is talked about more on [this thread)( What to look for in a power supply - #15 by usbcd36 ) (and especially this linked comment)

link_counts.title: What to look for in a power supply

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Thanks, that is useful.  In my case though, the most I am going to be doing is free-spinning two neos at once.  Given that I’m not going to be drawing that much current, is a 12 V DC power supply a viable option?

posts.name: Joey Tidrow
posts.cooked:
I would read through this thread. But if you get a 12 volt, high wattage from a trusted power supply manufacturer, you should be fine to run two free spinning neos with a current limit just to be safe.

Powering A Robot Testbed Via A Typical Wall Outlet Electrical

link_counts.title: Powering A Robot Testbed Via A Typical Wall Outlet

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
Definitely. You’ll need a regen clamp like this one to prevent the power supply from blowing due to the regeneration when the motors stop : ODrive Regen Clamp — ODrive

Automation Direct also has a couple. Any 12V ~20 to 50A supply off Amazon should work fine with a regen clamp. They’re cheap, so it can’t hurt to get a bigger one.

A clapped out 12v battery and a cheap charger shouldn’t be too expensive either. You’ll get hours of runtime if you’re not loading up the motors.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
I blew up a server power supply (an HP server part with 67A @ 12V rating with a single Spark Max and Neo by driving it (freewheeling) at full forward, then full reverse a few times. I’m not sure if it was current draw, back-EMF, or something else.

I think a low current limit and some limits on how fast you change speeds would be fine, but without a large amount of effective [and low impedance] capacitance (in the form of capacitors or a battery), I’d worry a bit about the longevity of a simple power supply if you’re going to do heavily dynamic motor control. (The server power supplies are also extremely cheap on Ebay, so it’s not the end of the world, but it’s annoying.)

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: Regen clamps will eat any current flowing back towards the power supply, protecting it from blowing when kicking a motor off or into reverse. You need one that’s sized for the load, but FRC motors aren’t storing that much energy at free speed.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
I agree dealing with back EMF is a need to protect the power supply.

At the point of the OP purchasing an $89 device and a power supply on top of that…

I would simply suggest you figure out how to get a battery, or simply purchase one and charge it off a charger your parents likely have at home or a small one you can likewise purchase for cheap.

I’ll second this recommendation. A 12V motorcycle or UPS battery costs $15-$20 and should do the job just fine.

edit: just be sure to charge it slower than you would an FRC competition battery.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: I didn’t realize that those regen clamps existed!  Cool!  Looks like I need to re-evaluate my two wall-powered test rigs!  I’m leaning toward some super capacitors.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Paraduks:

free-spinning two neos at once

If you can resist going over 0.1 (scale 0 to 1) for the 2 Neos then a $20 supply works. My team bought a few of these LRS-150-12 Amazon.com Needs a cord and plug from the junk box, too, and a switch is handy and safer.

Really want the oomph of two Neos at full no-load speed? I snatched from the garbage bin an old robot battery that we were scrapping. You need a charger. Team won’t let you borrow one? I bought this for my old car battery and it works great. (1 amp is slow but as fast as I need) https://www.amazon.com/NOCO-GENIUS1-Fully-Automatic-Temperature-Compensation/dp/B07W46BX31/ref=sr_1_7
